title: UK police arrest man and woman for human trafficking over truck deaths
text:
Two people were arrested on Friday (October 25) on suspicion of human trafficking, following the deaths of 39 people found in a truck in Essex - east of London on Wednesday (October 23).

A 38 year-old man and woman were detained in northwest England on suspicion of conspiracy to traffic people - and of 39 counts of manslaughter.





British police said they believed the victims were Chinese and China's Embassy in London said it had sent a team to Essex.

This as China called on Britain to seek "severe punishment" for those involved in the deaths.

Police say they are continuing to question the 25 year-old driver of the truck - who is yet to be formally identified, as a murder suspect.

A source familiar with the investigation named him as Mo Robinson from the Portadown area of Northern Ireland.





The refrigeration unit had traveled to Britain from Zeebrugge in Belgium.

The town's chairman said he believed the victims died in the trailer before it arrived in the Belgian port.

Private ambulances were seen at Tilbury Docks on Friday, as post-mortem examinations get underway in a bid to determine how exactly the 31 men and eight women died.

Forensic experts will seek to identify the deceased - something police warned would be a lengthy process.

China's Global Times, published by the ruling Communist Party's official People's Daily, said in a Friday editorial that Britain should bear some responsibility for the deaths.
